posts.title: day seven: back to dublin
posts.summary: after a long night of limping and hunting for food in a half-closed town, i ended up in a locals-only pub, got adopted by a guy named kevin who kept handing me guinness, and then caught the early bus back to dublin. there, i slipped some of my dad‚Äôs and bill‚Äôs ashes into the crypt at st. michan‚Äôs, swapped my heavy pack for lighter gear, saw friends, and heard live trad music ‚Äî and decided it was time to get my wrecked leg checked before pushing on.
posts.content:
> *\[ Edited: 10/25/2025 this is a repost of a series i wrote in 2022, migrating it to the new nostr website ]*

i finished the work zoom. that‚Äôs too kind: i finished frustratingly complaining to some vendors that were ignoring the issues that they caused on my network. to be taken from my vacation every night to deal with issues that shouldn‚Äôt be happening ‚Äî and to get no response from these guys for hours at a time ‚Äî i had to let them know that i was upset. while they knew i was out of the country, i shared with them WHY i was out of the country, that they were interrupting my ash-scattering journey. but enough of that. i chose not to dwell on it‚Ä¶ i was HUNGRY.

i walked around the town, looking for something open around dinner time. the river‚Äôs edge restaurant had great reviews and food photos, but only opened thursday through sunday. american style diner, also closed. my choices narrow down to pizza, chinese, or takeaway unless it‚Äôs thursday through sunday. i pop into a pub, andrew redmond and sons, on the way to pick up some takeaway, in hopes that maybe they served some pub grub.

‚Ä¶ they did not. this place was a hole in the wall, divey type of pub with one thing on the menu: booze. in fact, every head in the bar turned to look at me (record scratch! stop!) when i walked in. i think i found the locals bar! about 15 irish males, mostly in their 50s and 60s were watching soccer and throwing back guinnesses. while everyone turned to check me out, they quickly went back to what they were doing. so i hopped on a bar stool between an older dark haired man and a younger guy with wild unkempt hair. and promptly ordered a pint of the guinness. i finish two gulps of the beer in silence, trying to connect eyes with one of these guys to strike up a convo, but also keen to not interrupt their soccer match. i started to noticed a strong smell of urine, which made the beer taste off, and figure *eh‚Ä¶ i‚Äôll cut my losses, finish the beer and head out to mick the chipper, *the closest takeaway requiring the least number of body-numbing steps. as i am about to finish my beer, the wild-haired gent next to me hands me another guinness.

‚Äúble blah ble per **guinness **ple bler,‚Äù he said.

‚Äúoh thank you! wow.‚Äù i learned his name was kevin, and that even took some time to grok, as only every 5th word was audible and understandable sounding very much like popeye the sailor man‚Äôs under-the-breath mutterings.

we proceeded to attempt a discussion, me cluing into every 5th word and assuming what he said around it.

‚Äúblah blur be poer **bunclody** frem?‚Äù

‚Äúi just came from clonegall, the end of the wicklow way. i‚Äôm hiking my way across the country.‚Äù he smiled and nodded.

‚Äúoh pla berr stu **tent** per you **camp** innera?‚Äù

‚Äúyep, camping in a tent wherever i can. or when i need a shower, finding a town with a hotel. i‚Äôm at the clody lodge across the street tonight.‚Äù

this continues on, with him saying in the most clearly defined sentence he spoke ‚Äúhe‚Äôs doing what johnny did!‚Äù, to the darker haired fellow. that guy let out a hearty laugh and joined in the discussion. he was even harder to understand, with his words all tightly joined together into one beer-laced irish brogue.

a younger man enters from the backdoor with a cowboy hat on.

‚Äúdoinwhatjohnnydid!‚Äù they slur to him, nodding toward me.

i could easily understand this guy, who was maybe 50 years old at most, very fit, and hadn‚Äôt yet had 10 beers to change his speech. he hikes routinely, but not for the last few years as he has 2 young children at the house now. in fact, he just popped in for a quick pint before he had to go pick up his daughter at dance class. he gave me a few pointers for the south leinster way, which i would be starting shortly. but he also suggested, like others before, to skip the next few legs and go over to the ring of kerry or the dingle peninsula and hike that instead. ‚Äús‚Äôthe best use of yer time here!‚Äù

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/7af491af94dfcd862df1310181beedf3.gif?w=1024)

i finished the second pint and told kevin and my new friends that would return after i got something to eat. i headed to mick the chipper and got some beef curry and then back to my hotel room with that new annoying limp, the guinnesses not helping my leg feel any better. (‚Äúguinness for health‚Äù my ass!) i downed the curry in 5 minutes: it was quite excellent or i was incredibly famished. i thought about my new friends waiting at redmond‚Äôs ‚Äî but decided to go to bed instead. i didn‚Äôt have the mental capacity to decipher the conversation anymore, anyway. plus, i had to get up early to catch one of the only two buses out of town.

in the middle of the night, i woke up with a painful cramp in the calf of the gimp leg. i threw off the covers and tried to stand up quickly or i knew i would be writhing in pain and unable to get up to relieve it. walking around is the only way to get rid of them. i remember wondering *where am i*? with only a dim light coming from the crack under the door, i couldn‚Äôt make out the furniture based on the shadows. *am i in tent? am i back in philly? am i in mick‚Äôs house*? it takes 20 seconds for my mind to adjust and recall i‚Äôm in bunclody. i shake my head aggressively, as if to snap myself back to reality, and lie back down.

## \~\~\~\~\~

i wake up feeling groggy. i didn‚Äôt sleep well, tossing and turning constantly. that‚Äôs not like me; i am able to sleep anywhere at anytime. but between my ailing leg and my mind overly alert from a new place every night, i just couldn‚Äôt get comfortable. i see it‚Äôs 6 am on my watch. *oh well, i missed the first bus.* i pack up and walk down to the supermarket to inquire about the bus transit system. the store clerk was just opening his doors. he‚Äôs a very friendly fellow, more helpful than i had anticipated. he assured me i could pay with paper money and they would give me change, even though the bus websites said that they wouldn‚Äôt.

while waiting for the bus, i talked with an older woman, mary, who must take the bus regularly. she told me about how so many places in town closed from the restrictive lockdowns for covid (people couldn‚Äôt leave a specific, eventually expanding, perimeter around their hometown in ireland). she also theorized that there weren‚Äôt enough chefs or workers in general to keep everything open. she noted that on a random wednesday night at 9pm, the town center would be empty right now because people got used to (or even enjoyed) staying in for the night instead of walking about town. optimistically, she mentioned that several new places have already opened ‚Äúon the edges of the town.‚Äù it‚Äôs a shame that they aren‚Äôt opening in the middle of town, but i imagine the rent is more expensive. you would think building owners would negotiate to get their spaces filled, yet many stores remained closed or boarded up. she mentioned that they were investing big money in a hotel near the golf course, too, again on the edge of town.

the loss of main streets has also hit america hard. when small towns lose their economic engines in the center of town, the whole town suffers. and, even more drastically, you start to loosen the threads that keep a tight-knit community together. when you‚Äôre not walking to the store and saying hello to your neighbors ‚Äî catching up on town happenings or just generally keeping in touch ‚Äî community seems to unwind. i have experienced this in america, and it would pain me to see it happen in small-town ireland. that‚Äôs one of the things, i think, that makes me enjoy going there so much. everyone knows everyone, and they all know when a traveler is coming through. i hope the world can recover quickly from this.

the bus arrives, the driver opens the door. ‚Äúaw goo‚Äômornin‚Äô mary! headed to baltinglass?‚Äù ‚Äúg‚Äômorning luv, aye i am.‚Äù he gives me a similarly affable greeting and asks where i am headed. i pay the ‚Ç¨14.50 requested to city center and sit down behind mary. i listen as the bus driver greets every person getting on the bus by name while anticipating their destination. this happened not just in bunclody, but all along the route he has probably driven for the past decade or more.

‚Äúhiyya jackie, headed to dublin city center?‚Äù he asked.

‚Äúye, i‚Äôm t‚Äôirsty and want to see if there‚Äôs any more rain up there.‚Äù he jokes, as bunclody just went through a 3 day rainstorm before i arrived.

‚Äúoh they had lots last night,‚Äù he replied. somehow i kept missing the rain. when i wasn‚Äôt in dublin, it was raining there. before i arrived in bunclody, it rained there. my path was optimally (by sheer luck) avoiding all precipitation.

i spent the bus ride writing, drifting in and out of thought, occasionally interrupted by someone getting on or off the bus. before i knew it, i looked up and saw the ha‚Äôpenny bridge in dublin over the river liffey. *oh! i‚Äôm right near st. michan‚Äôs!* i told the driver i was getting off at the next stop instead.

st. michan‚Äôs is this hidden gem in dublin. it‚Äôs a very old, still-active church that has a crypt underneath it with often times stacked coffins. it is obviously illegal to bust open coffins and disturb the deceased‚Äôs remains, but sometimes the wood gives way and the coffin collapses on itself. during the cleanup of one such instance, the mummified remains of several bodies were exposed in the crypt many years ago. there are theories as to why the remains are mummified (limestone basement walls creating a dry environment, methane gas from being built on a former swampland). whatever is preserving their bodies is also destroying the wood. the main room has 4 mummies in it, two women and two men. the one man had his feet chopped off, suspected of being a thief (but later possibly becoming a priest, which would explain being in the crypt). the two women were well preserved. the prized jewel here is a 900 year old mummy believed to be a crusader. this soldier was incredibly tall (estimated to be 6‚Ä≤ 5‚Ä≥, which was giant-size in his world). his legs were broken in half and folded under him so that he could fit into the coffin!

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4253.jpg?w=1024)

> the main mummy room

my dad went to st. michan‚Äôs in 2003, and he got such a kick out of the (quite excellent) tour guide that he refused to let people go to dublin without insisting that they checked out st. michan‚Äôs crypts. peter, as i later learned was his name as he is still doing the tours nearly 20 years later, starts the tour with a ‚Äúso you want to see the mummies?‚Äù or a ‚Äúso you are here to see the crypt?‚Äù in an impression of the ‚Äòtales from the crypt‚Äô cryptkeeper‚Äôs gait and voice.

when i came myself in 2003 (and again in 2012 and 2015), at my dad‚Äôs urging, the crusader had his hand extended out of the coffin. and the finger looked petrified. as the tour went on back then, a superstition was revealed to us that rubbing the finger while making a wish would ensure it came true. so of course about half of every hourly tour was not grossed out enough to rub the finger for luck. sadly, the hand was not extended anymore. i asked peter what happened, and he told us that in 2019, the crypt was broken into and desecrated. The Crusader‚Äôs head and some bones were stolen, the women were turned over in their grave, and the thief was decapitated. they eventually found the vandal, and thus the bones and head, but the extended hand collapsed and disintegrated to a point that it was no longer safe to touch. what a bummer! people can really be such assholes.

<https://blossom.primal.net/51fbec9ed528067ef1a378f4a18e3d0d7714eda7f6f44234c2571eb20707e7e3.mp4>

> the cryptkeeper (so worth the ‚Ç¨7 tour fee!)

i had a great chat with peter for 10-15 minutes as the other tour guests left. i told him all about my dad‚Äôs love of him and this tour, that my dad had probably sent close to 100 people his way‚Ä¶ and about my adventure spreading ashes across ireland. i asked if i could drop some ashes down below in the crypt. he said ‚Äúno‚Äù but winked when he said it‚Ä¶ or at least i thought i saw a wink. so i dropped a small pinch of bill‚Äôs and my dad‚Äôs ashes sneakily so the other tour guests didn‚Äôt see. my dad would certainly love to know that a little bit of him is down there with the mummies. considering bill‚Äôs skull tattoos, he‚Äôd probably get a kick out of it too!

<https://blossom.primal.net/cccab5029842b21c33fc8f83dc1e36667e903ba508d9b8a7fc91b296fc6710fb.mp4>

> scattering ashes in the crypt. oops busted, left my flash on!

walking out of the church, i remembered that my friend chalk (my housemate trevor‚Äôs girlfriend) was in ireland with her family. we had intentionally made no promises of meeting up while we both were in the emerald island; if fate brought us together in the same area at the same time, so be it! i shot her a text. ‚Äúhey i am randomly back in dublin to ditch some weight for the night.‚Äù then i hopped in a cab to head back to mick and ann marie‚Äôs to drop off my bag. still wearing my hiking boots, i was somewhat desperate to put on something more comfortable for street walking. traveling as lightly as possible, however, i didn‚Äôt have any other shoes. ann marie graciously took me to the mall after we surprised the girls by picking them up at their schools. they were shocked to see me so soon! they thought it would be 3 weeks until they saw me, so i got some running leaps, hugs, and screams of ‚Äòbriannn!‚Äô.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4260.jpg?w=1024)

> uncle b hates his ice cream

at the mall, i bought some cozy nikes (pronounced with one syllable in ireland‚Ä¶ rhymes with mike‚Äôs) and some ankle hugging thin non-hiking socks. my feet were feeling pretty happy (my lower leg was another story, but the pain was tolerable until i overused it by the end of the day). of course, we were at the mall with uncle b‚Ä¶ so i treated the girls to some ridiculously large ice cream sundaes. we headed back to the house and drew portraits of each other. clodagh told me hers was ‚Äúway better‚Äù than mine (and made herself a medal for beating me!). i let her win that one because chalk had just texted me back that she happened to be in dublin as well, and they were planning to go to a traditional irish music jam session. perfect!

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_9009.jpg?w=768)

> got to hang with chalk without hiking boots

i hopped onto the bus and made my way back down into city center. we hung out at the cobblestone pub, staying for several hours to enjoy the live trad music. i was constantly impressed with how musicians joined and left the music circle so seamlessly that the melodious sounds never stopped. it was impressive and delighted my ears. pub patrons would sometimes get loud, talking to each other with voices rising as the ambient noise in the bar picked up. the bartenders would occasionally politely say ‚Äúthis IS a music bar, please be quiet.‚Äù and they would shut up for a few minutes until the sounds built to a crescendo again. enter the tin flute. this old white-haired jolly irish gentleman was playing the tin flute, and he seemed to have control over the crowd volume without effort. the second he started playing, the room got quiet. it was beautiful and peacful, or haunting and eery, but always melodic. he was a master. and he earned his respect, apparently. i couldn‚Äôt get over how no one dared make a peep the moment the first note left his flute, every time.

<https://blossom.primal.net/6ed3209e408004231f228bb1b88b75536e61c97768cfff9e03eee59266e2c831.mp4>

> cobblestone pub

we had a fantastic meal around the corner at oscar‚Äôs cafe bar (thank you for the recommendation to the bartender, and to chalk‚Äôs aunt and uncle for treating!) and then mary pat, chalk and i went to *brazen head*, the oldest pub in dublin, for a night cap as mary pat‚Äôs parents went home. we were all pretty exhausted, but i could tell that mary pat, being younger than chelsea and i, was still ready to rip it. she had decided that she was moving to ireland and even checked out some rental properties while she was here. i wish i had it in me to stay out past midnight, but i was eager to get back on the trail the next morning, so i didn‚Äôt. we did however do a celebratory shot of whiskey with her before calling it a night.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4276.jpg?w=1024)

this was a good diversion, a good idea to come back to dublin. i got to see chelsea (and meet her family) and reduce my load before continuing. consensus was that i should get my leg checked out before i headed south and continued my trek across the motherland.

so that became my plan.

do you agree, chalk?

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_6356.jpg?w=768)

> she agrees.

\#travel #ireland2022

posts.title: day six: finishing the wicklow way
posts.summary: SERIES REPOST 2022: day six (~22 miles; ~103 total) hurt like hell ‚Äî my left leg was blowing up, every step felt like a knife, and i still pushed to finish the wicklow way, score a secret pub pint, and get my completion certificate from an older couple who‚Äôve been blessing hikers for decades. i limped into bunclody swollen, borderline broken, and made the call to bus back to dublin, drop weight, and face the fact that my body might be done, even if my head isn‚Äôt.
posts.content:
> *\[ Edited: 10/25/2025 this is a repost of a series i wrote in 2022, migrating it to the new nostr website ]*

**DAY SIX HIKE**: \~22 miles\
**TOTAL MILES**: \~103 miles

\[**NOTE**: i am home early and finishing up the outlined posts i have in my draft queue. i am okay, disappointed to be home early, but on the mend.]

*something isn‚Äôt right with my leg. if this is what overused feels like, i don‚Äôt want to think about the marathon training i have to start in about a month. are these shin splints? i‚Äôve never had them before. maybe i have a stress fracture? can i continue on at this pace? should i stay in tinahely another night and crash that wedding?* thoughts race through my head as i get ready for bed, wanting nothing more than a fresh pair of socks to soothe my throbbing feet. *i need to consult my running friends about shin splints, get some advice.* i dig through my ruck sack for my charger, and i miraculously remembered that, as i was walking out of my west philly bedroom, i threw one more pair of clean socks into the tiny pocket under my water bottle. *was that a dream, or did i really spoil myself?* i eagerly sought to find out, tearing open the zipper and ‚Äî out popped the overstuffed clean fabric of two waterproof socks. i didn‚Äôt think i could be so happy from a pair of clean socks. i immediately put them on and laid down in comfort, ready for sleep. i don‚Äôt usually sleep with socks on at home, but the tightness of these waterproof socks was instantly soothing.

i woke up at 7am. my body feels rested from a good night‚Äôs sleep. my right foot calmed down but my left foot and lower leg still had the echos of the previous day‚Äôs 20-mile hike. i knew when i started hiking, that echo would turn louder into a full-on scream. but the show must go on.¬† wake, yoga, teeth, pack. ready for my full irish! the typical breakfast was served from 9 to 11 am. because i requested an earlier exit, the chef himself sat me in an empty dining room. this was great, because it gave us time to chat.

‚Äúfinishing the wicklow way, huh? ugh‚Äù he says with a dismissive swipe of the forearm in disgust. ‚Äúthis last part isn‚Äôt worth it. don‚Äôt do it. it‚Äôs like 70% on roads with cars. the only good part is the shebeen.‚Äù¬†

‚Äúthe what?‚Äù

‚Äúthe shebeen. illegal pub.‚Äù

‚Äúoh! like a speakeasy. where‚Äôs that?‚Äù

‚Äúlook for ‚Äòthe dying cow‚Äô pub. there‚Äôs no sign, just a white building. it used to be a shebeen. legit now, tho. it‚Äôs been in the same family for the last three hundred years.‚Äù

i looked it up really quickly to see how far off the trail it was. ‚Äúoh man, it says it doesn‚Äôt open until 11 am. i will be passing by around 10.‚Äù

‚Äúoh just knock up! tha woman who runs it will serve you a pint. she‚Äôs 90 years old. knock loudly!‚Äù

i devour the complimentary full irish, and realize i don‚Äôt have any coins for a tip. i told him i would be right back. i walked over to the fruit stand and got 2 apples for my hike and brought my man back a ‚Ç¨2 coin for a tip, for which he was surprised and grateful.

i grab my bag and set off for the day. instead of backtracking up to the trail 1.5 miles, i take the road that goes right to ‚Äòthe dying cow.‚Äô the routes took roughly the same time to traverse, and the bar is right on the wicklow way, conveniently. it would take me about 2 hours to get there.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4197.jpg?w=1024)

> more gorgeous than sausages?

i follow the gps and pass a lot of cars heading to work or driving children to school. i was definitely walking with a little bit of a limp, with my left leg not fully cooperating. i pass several old men gardening, and exchange a g‚Äômornin‚Äô with each. with a white building in my field of view, atop a hill looking down on cow pastures, i get excited for a cold guinness. i start walking down the hill, watching google maps to see which of the white buildings on the horizon might be this unmarked shebeen.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4198.jpg?w=1024)

> crosses and cows

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4199.jpg?w=1024)

> lots of white buildings, where‚Äôs ‚Äòthe cow‚Äô

two young guys approached me, looking more lost than me.

‚Äúhey bruh. can you help? you know how to get to the shops?‚Äù

‚Äúi can try. you see this backpack tho?‚Äù i said pointing to my back. ‚Äúi‚Äôm just passing through! what shops?‚Äù

‚Äúi know there are shops close to here. he says it‚Äôs that way,‚Äù he said pointing northwest, ‚Äúbut i think it‚Äôs that way‚Äù, pointing due south.

‚Äúumm, i just came from a little village about 1.5 hours away that has a bunch of shops,‚Äù i mentioned, throwing my thumb toward the southeast direction behind me.

‚Äúno, it‚Äôs closer than that.‚Äù

‚Äúok, let‚Äôs see if i can pull up google maps satellite.‚Äù we search the nearby areas for what might appear from the sky to be shops. most look like farms or solo structures from above, nothing really resembling a town center. ‚Äúwhere are you coming from?‚Äù

‚Äúup the street bruh‚Äù they pointed to where i was headed.

‚Äúoh do yo know ‚Äòthe dying cow‚Äô?‚Äù

‚Äúoh course man! we were there last night. so fun! no one is there now. we just moved here from south africa. just trying to figure out where ‚Äòhere‚Äô is tho.‚Äù

i tell them what i am doing, walking coast to coast, spreading my dad‚Äôs and bill‚Äôs ashes. and that i am about 85 miles into my trek. i laughed and continued to hunt for stores. ‚Äúhere‚Äôs a town about an hour away. but it only looks like 1 or 2 shops.‚Äù¬†

‚Äúnah, not it. can i look?‚Äù i hand him my phone and he starts scrolling through the map tiles. ‚Äúoh this looks like it‚Ä¶ tinahely.‚Äù

‚Äúthat‚Äôs where i just came from!‚Äù

‚Äúoh man, and it‚Äôs an hour and a half walk? that‚Äôs sucks‚Äù¬†

‚Äújust about. but i have a back pack and a limp, you can do it faster.‚Äù

‚Äúhere we are complaining about 3 miles, and dis oom‚Äôs walking 380.‚Äù the quieter of the two spoke up, laughing.

‚Äúmake a left at the stone cross down that hill, and it‚Äôs basically straight ahead. good luck guys!‚Äù

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4205.jpg?w=1024)

> tallon‚Äôs ‚Äòthe dying cow‚Äô pub

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4207.jpg?w=1024)

> what a drinking view!

i walk up the hill and immediately noticed small signage for ‚Äòthe dying cow:‚Äô proof the chef probably hadn‚Äôt been here in a while. the place was empty, the doors were shut, the lights were off. after my 20 minute chat with the south africans, it was around 10:40, so i figured i could wait until the advertised 11 am opening. i dropped mr. osprey and looked around. there‚Äôs a great tree trunk carving of a hiker and his dog across the street. there are two seprate seating areas with small fireplaces adjacent. this was very clearly a small side addition to a farmhouse where the proprietress probably lived. this would have been an incredible pub to hang out in for a few hours. my breakfast chef told me they were very welcoming to hikers and allowed people to pitch tents in the backyard all the time (i wish i had known that and planned for it!). not only did the pub have a sign, it also had two historical plaques with two different stories about the name of the pub (so very irish), which i combined into one for clarity here:

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4200.jpg?w=768)

> wood carving outside the pub

‚ÄúThe name of the pub originated from an incident said to have happened around the 1920‚Äôs when a group of people were caught drinking there on a Sunday night. According to the rules, to qualify for late night or all day drinking on a Sunday in Ireland and Great Britain, one is required to have ‚Äútravelled in good faith for a distance of three miles, by public thoroughfare, from the place they spent the night.‚Äù Travelling in good faith meant that you could not be ‚Äútravelling for the purpose of taking refreshment‚Äù‚Ä¶ the elderly landlady tried all her charm to the Guardi claiming ‚ÄúSure you wouldn‚Äôt summons an old woman! These men were only helping me with a dying cow.‚Äù ‚Ä¶ The pub has a long tradition of card playing and an assumption upon entering that you leave your feelings and emotions at the door.‚Äù

and here‚Äôs an even more elaborate and colorful irish retelling of the story ‚Äî which i highly recommend you read. [*https://medium.com/@mtallon245/an-irishmans-story-part-one-36dfe4d0a330*](https://medium.com/@mtallon245/an-irishmans-story-part-one-36dfe4d0a330)

at 10:55, one of the doors swung open. i assumed it was the owner opening up. i walked into those doors very excitedly, anticipating a cold guinness‚Ä¶ but it was just the water closets. no one was around, no entrance into the main pub. a wind gust must have opened the door. how disappointing!

i walk back outside, walk all the way around the building, and peek into any window i could. it‚Äôs so painfully adorable in there, but it‚Äôs also dark and still. no one is around. 11 am hits. no one opens the door. 11:15, i knock on the front door to the pub and to the farmhouse. no one answers. i think back to the hotel chef telling me that the owner is a 90 year old woman. ‚Äúlet her sleep in, brian!‚Äù i waited 5 more minutes, and left disappointed. my heart as empty as my stomach. no guiness for me. no dying cow drinking story to relay when i got home. i made a mental note to come back here next time i come to ireland. this is my kind of place.

https://blossom.primal.net/2d0003034895a9864e373c74555d63004ad4782dbf5fbe3342c28038bd369e5a.mp4

> straight outta ‚Äòthe birds‚Äô

as i hope back onto the trail, i feel like i am in the movie ‚Äòthe birds.‚Äô hundreds of crows are cawing and swooping through the gorgeous skies. it‚Äôs as if there actually IS a dying cow and they‚Äôre all waiting to eat.

i thought about my dad‚Äôs love of horror movies, and how he passed that along to many of us. i thought about how he would wait until the climax right before a scare, and throw a pillow at you from across the room with a loud yelp of terror. (this got you every time, and you‚Äôd jump out of your skin, even during movies you watched with him a dozen times). i thought about his love for halloween, and our resultant traditions of dressing up to scare the trick or treaters, haunted house style. and how amazingly fun it is. they were fleeting thoughts, but they were a nice distraction from my left leg.

i continued the hike. this chef was correct in that this segment ran along a lot more roads. but i was still enjoying it. i started walking along a road with cows grazing on both sides of it. on my left, in the much bigger pasture full of heather flowers, grass, and sun, i see three groups of cows. they are separated from each other. but they all take a break from chewing to look at me. i laugh, thinking back to a road trip to my dad‚Äôs brother Jim‚Äôs farm in upstate new york. we are driving along in our 25 foot van, lovingly called ‚Äúthe fish tank‚Äù by my friends growing up. i‚Äôm sure it was a perfect time to stay inside your own head with random thoughts: 10 kids packed in like sardines, without air conditioning or a radio, for an 8-10 hour drive (uncle steve loves to retell this story, but i‚Äôm more remembering one random thought he shared along this ride). as my dad is driving, he‚Äôs watching the cows in the fields. deep in thought he blurts out, ‚Äúdo you think cows have gangs?‚Äù

https://blossom.primal.net/365f21d4024dc3d7484a5155111e528a3715ba48bf5aee6cb9131996d7e8b4f5.mp4

we all laughed, but as i watched how they stayed in packs, you can definitely see why that thought popped up. i keep walking. i notice the field on the right is much smaller, not as sunny for whatever reason, and only had one cow gang in it. *these guys must be from the wrong side of the track*, i think to myself proud of my dad joke, walking on the physical track of which i speak.

https://blossom.primal.net/f372d26b74eff60088cfd8a728ee83b5a4e721f48c2fcc9e2ac6595f8de2d6cc.mp4

but they didn‚Äôt find it funny. the cows started following me! every time i turned around they would stop moving and pretend that they weren‚Äôt obviously trailing me ‚Äî *running* at times! i started laughing hard at this. i couldn‚Äôt believe they were doing it. i finally took out my camera to try to record them, and they stopped all together. busted! they were made!

now, this reminded me of a gary larson cartoon. my dad and i loved the far side comics. i kept waking and laughing in disbelief. i‚Äôm assuming the cows thought they were about to be fed? it got me pretty good tho.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4449.jpg?w=823)

> gary was a genius

i kept walking, kept the pace. i tried to ignore the fact that every step after about 5 miles in, was agony. *i need to at least finish the wicklow way. i can‚Äôt stop before that!* i took a break on a stone wall and ate an apple. i pulled out my map to strategize. at the start of the morning, i had about 18.5 miles in total to get to clonegall, the end of the wicklow way and the start of the south leinster way. i was about 3/4 of the way there. i had checked online multiple times for a place to stay in clonegall but i couldn‚Äôt find anything. there were some wild camping spots that were my original destination target, but i needed wifi to have a zoom meeting for work (ugh, i know). i was disappointed i couldn‚Äôt escape work, but some things only i can handle. i scouted a town nearby (\~1.5 hours by foot) that had a hotel, so i booked that and figured, what‚Äôs another 3.5 miles? with the hotel booked, i continued on to clonegall.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4211.jpg?w=1024)

there were parts of this trail that got dangerous. not because of the terrain, but because of the speeding cars driving on not-wide-enough roads. several times i jammed myself into a thorn bush overhanging the road to give a farmer‚Äôs equipment room to get by. i got to a safe cutout, the entrance to a sheep farm, and drop my bag. i take a knee and have a piss. i haven‚Äôt seen anyone most of the day, so was surprised when a sheep farmer asked if i was okay. ‚Äúi‚Äôm good! just having a rest!‚Äù i quickly finished relieving myself before he came over ‚Äî but he went to opposite direction to tend to his flock. whew.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4230.jpg?w=1024)

> clonegall: picturesque indeed!

i finally make it to clonegall, and i am relieved. THE END of the wicklow way. this is a very picturesque village, but it was almost too much like a painting in that there was no movement at all, aside from the flowing river.

**man this is anticlimactic!**

at the end of the wicklow way, i didn‚Äôt know what to expect. but a town with no one walking around, no one there to say ‚Äòhey good on you!‚Äô, was not it. i recalled what mickey said to me when i was questioning whether to reactivate social media for this trip: ‚Äúremember, you‚Äôre not doing this for anyone but yourself.‚Äù that applies here too; i guess i don‚Äôt need to see anyone here. i‚Äôll check out the village really quickly and then head to the town of bunclody for my hotel.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4220.jpg?w=1024)

> off in the distance, the lovely couple ready their pub for tomorrow‚Äôs opening

as i‚Äôm taking some photos of the nearby castle, and trying to capture the cuteness of the town, i see an old man and woman come out to clean the light on what looks like the only pub in town, OSBORNE. okay maybe they are just about to open!

by the time i walked up to the bar, it‚Äôs just the old man on the ladder, cleaning the inside glass of the light. he clearly cared about this place.

‚Äúhi there! are you open?‚Äù

‚Äúno, no.‚Äù and that was all he said. i paused waiting for anything else, but it didn‚Äôt come.

‚Äúoh, okay. is there anywhere open here to grab a drink or lunch?‚Äù

‚Äúare ye starting the wicklow way?‚Äù he looked away from the light and at me for the first time.

‚Äúi just finished!‚Äù

‚Äúoh! come in. come in. my wife has a certificate for you.‚Äù

‚Äúoh really? that‚Äôs great!‚Äù he slowly gets down from the ladder, as a septuagenarian should. i offer to carry his supplies in, but he just motions for me to go in ahead of him.¬†

‚Äúhe just finished! he needs a certificate!‚Äù

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4225.jpg?w=1024)

> shelves appear to float and maintain gravity‚Äôs laws at the same time‚Ä¶ how did i not ask this couple for a photo with them, they were amazing!

the bar is dark, and in slight disarray. but it looks like something out of a harry potter set, with unleveled shelves somehow delicately holding up racks of bottles, with a bar-top made out of surplus coffin lids, with atmospheric lighting welcoming you deeper into the bar and if you‚Äôre lucky, into the back room that has a fireplace. i learn that they are only open thursday through sunday nights. this was a wednesday, so sadly i am left out again. she confirms my suspicion that their hours are due to covid lockdowns and the travel sector not fully revived yet‚Ä¶ but i think their old age may also have something to do with it. it was wednesday and they were finally getting around to tidying up from sunday‚Äôs open hours.

‚Äúcan i pour ya a pint?‚Äù

‚Äúi‚Äôd love to buy one‚Äù i say, making sure she knows i‚Äôm not looking for a handout. man, i love this irish couple so much.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4227.jpg?w=768)

> WOO HOO! official date stamp and everything!

i learn that they have been giving out these certificates since the wicklow way opened, some 30 years ago. i‚Äôm sure she has seen it all, heard every story. she told me about a girl last week from australia that broke down in tears at the bar. when she asked what was wrong, the girl told her that she had just completed the wicklow way in seven days. she was fine for the first four days, but she was so incredibly lonely the last three days. she couldn‚Äôt handle it, and kept trying to find a way to quit. so i asked, ‚Äúwere these tears of joy that she finished?‚Äù the woman replied ‚Äúi don‚Äôt think she knew!‚Äù

i told her that i started at poolbeg lighthouse, 9 miles from marlay park. and that i took the day off yesterday to heal. so leaving the trail like that for a hotel, and more importantly a bath that i could soak in, presented me with lots of people i could talk to. i haven‚Äôt really felt lonely at all on the trip. i had read lots of reviews about people taking these long multi-day hikes and feeling very lonely. i guess i just know that i‚Äôm close enough to a town that i could walk to and start up a conversation? it also helps that i have my cell phone on me, with data turned on (i couldn‚Äôt negotiate my way out of that, work required it. my original plan was no cell phone. my mom would have killed me if i tried that tho). her husband walks in with the ladder as i‚Äôm finishing my second pint. i felt weird drinking while they were cleaning, but they seemed to enjoy the company.

‚Äúthis war isn‚Äôt ending anytime soon. putin won‚Äôt stop.‚Äù he says out of nowhere.

‚Äúyeah it‚Äôs terrible! if he gets away with taking ukraine, he‚Äôll roll into the next country right away.‚Äù

he paused in thought. ‚Äúgreed is an odd thing, isn‚Äôt it‚Äù he says shaking his head. clearly this man does not have a greedy bone in his body. working the same small bar for decades in a simple and happy life. ‚Äúdo you have a place to stay? lots of refugees right now.‚Äù

‚Äúi couldn‚Äôt find anything in clonegall so i‚Äôm headed to bunclody.‚Äù i finish the small bag of potato crisps that they gave me, and drank the last sip from the third pint. i had walking to do, as much as i‚Äôd rather hang out. i remembered ben franklin‚Äôs quote ‚Äúfish and company smell after three days‚Äù and assumed it applied to beers at a closed pub as well. three pints and don‚Äôt overstay your welcome.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4213.jpg?w=1024)

> shillelagh detour, cute af

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4214.jpg?w=1024)

> town famous for their walking (band battle!) sticks made of blackthorn

i load my pack onto my back and head south. every step i make with my left leg feels like someone is stabbing me on the shin and dragging the knife up to my knee or down to the top of my foot. it was not comfortable. as i‚Äôm walking, i take out my phone and check to see if bunclody is big enough for a routine bus schedule. (many small villages don‚Äôt have public transportation options, or have a once or twice a week bus roll through). bunclody has 2 busses to dublin tomorrow at 6 am and 7:50am. BINGO! i‚Äôm going to go back to dublin in the morning and swap out this huge backpack for a smaller day bag. the next section of the trail can weave through a town every night, so i can carefully plan my route to avoid camping (and about 30 lbs of gear). this is my answer! i‚Äôll come back to dublin in a week and get the camp gear for the kerry way and beara way. surely this will relieve whatever is going on with my leg.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4232.jpg?w=1024)

> friendly greeting by two asses

i‚Äôm so distracted by my thoughts that i don‚Äôt realize i‚Äôm already almost in bunclody. i arrive, find my hotel, and ditch my bag all in short order. i take off my shoes, and i sit staring at my left leg. it looks like the pillsbury dough boy wearing a sweater three sizes too small. i am so swollen. my right leg feels pretty great, all things considered. the rest of my body felt fine. i thought it was weird to get shin splints in one leg. so i started thinking *maybe it was a stress fracture*. *maybe i shouldn‚Äôt be doing 22 mile hikes, like today. maybe while i‚Äôm in dublin i should go get this checked out before i come back down. maybe‚Ä¶*

oh shit!

i have a work zoom in 10 minutes. let me look presentable. i hopped in the shower, tried to shift my focus to 3300 miles away back in america.

my body couldn‚Äôt have felt farther from my mind than at that moment.

posts.title: #2400 - Katee Sackhoff

posts.title: day five: one of rest
posts.summary: SERIES REPOST 2022: day five was tinahely: soaking wrecked legs, eating a full irish, and stumbling into this tiny wicklow village‚Äôs real heartbeat ‚Äî a holy well tied to st. patrick where i left some of dad and bill‚Äôs ashes, and a rowdy pre-wedding pub night where strangers adopted me as ‚Äúthe yank.‚Äù i suppose i didn't rest much, yet i refilled everything that mattered.
posts.content:
**DAY FIVE ‚ÄúREST‚Äù HIKE**: 7 miles

my initial impression of tinahely, as i shuffled through the streets to find murphy‚Äôs hotel, was that covid hit it kind of hard. there were several boarded up shops, including maggie‚Äôs pub and a black tom‚Äôs bar. both had good reviews on google so i‚Äôm assuming they were covid fatalities. it was a small village, with a unique triangular ‚Äútown square‚Äù in the middle of it (how irish!).

after being checked in, i did as anticipated: a hot soak almost immediately, right after taking my boots off the second i walked in the door. i counted four blisters either forming or fully developed. i had a weird bruise at the base of my big toe. i stayed in the very long tub for a very long hour. it was a luxury to have a tub a tall man could actually fit in. they know what‚Äôs up. i cleaned my feet well, and noticed a weird ripple of skin on the underside of my foot, like a peak and valley i climbed earlier that day. touching it didn‚Äôt feel great. but it felt like the foot was starting to prune up. so i got out. i laid down and told myself 5 minutes.

an hour later i got up and went down for a burger and a beer. i tried to strike up a conversation with the bartender, with the locals i sat next to, with anyone but a sheep or a cow. no one was very chatty. and the accents were very hard to chew through. i‚Äôm decent at hearing and deciphering a brogue, but for them i certainly needed subtitles. maybe it‚Äôs just because it was beer o‚Äôclock, and my brain was as tired as my legs.

that‚Äôs odd. this is the first irish town i‚Äôve been to that didn‚Äôt feel very welcoming to me. i knew that couldn‚Äôt be true: it had to just be my mood. murphy‚Äôs hotel pub might just be a quiet type of bar. i finished my meal with enough pleasantries and small talk, but mostly overhearing the bartender chat up the guys that probably sit on the same stool every day. ‚Äúbrendan fell asleep making a pizza. the fooker burnt it black. luckily i came home and took it out of the oven. whole place filled with smoke. he woke up and looks at me an says ‚Äòthe fook did ya do to me pizza?‚Äô‚Äù they let out a belly laugh. that part i understood. laughter is a universal language. i was beat, and so i went to bed at maybe 9.

i woke up feeling more myself. i should have apologized to my bag for kicking him over but the emotions of the day got to me. i did some yoga, and noticed that my lower legs still really didn‚Äôt feel great. the tops of my feet felt like a taught rubber band about to snap. the blisters contorted to my boot‚Äôs insoles but didn‚Äôt burst. i went down for a ‚Äúfull irish‚Äù. my dad would have been appalled that it took me 6 days in ireland before i had a full irish.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4135.jpg?w=962)

> full irish

a full irish is a hearty meal fit for field work ‚Äî or a hiker. 2 eggs, gorgeous irish sausage, irish bacon, white pudding and blood pudding (these are akin to scrapple, kind of), mushrooms, grilled tomato, and baked beans. complete with tea and irish brown bread slathered with kerrygold butter, it‚Äôs a dang feast. i don‚Äôt usually eat the mushrooms or the blood pudding ‚Äî the mushrooms make it taste too fungus-y and the blood makes it tastes too iron-y for me. but this hotel had a pretty good one. ‚Äúcan i add another night to my stay?‚Äù ‚Äúsure t‚Äôing!‚Äù i gobbled it up and went to check out the town a bit.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4139.jpg?w=1024)

> green cuisine: fresh fruits and veg

around the first bend, the first thing i see is a fruit stand. and what do we do when we see a fruit stand? right, we check the prices! my dad couldn‚Äôt go by someone selling fruits and vegetables without checking out the quality, the price, and if there was any varietal he didn‚Äôt know. the only thing that was different here, though, were some of the names (not ‚Äúred delicious‚Äù but ‚Äúred chief‚Äù, not ‚Äúarugula‚Äùbut ‚Äúrocket‚Äù). it‚Äôs kind of wild that our food is so similar thousands of miles away. this store was screaming vibes of tony‚Äôs produce and flounders‚Äô produce, my dad‚Äôs old produce stores. i looked around, chatted up the proprietress, and bought a couple of apples. and smiled the whole time.

i kept walking through town. noticing the different stores, many were named murphy‚Äôs like the hotel. murphy‚Äôs butcher, murphy‚Äôs leather, murphy furniture warehouse. and then there was coffee dlite and o‚Äôconnor‚Äôs bar and lounge. i took mental notes to return to those two. no one was really walking around town, so i went back up to my room to do a little writing. an hour or two later, i come back down for the coffee shop. i notice a sign in the town triangle that had lots of nearby landmarks listed. some of them would have been cool to check out with a car.

one landmark at the bottom right caught my eye. Toberpatrick Holy Well. wait, patrick, huh? what‚Äôs that! i read the little description and see it‚Äôs wicklow‚Äôs best preserved drinking well from the time of ‚Äî and blessed by ‚Äî st. patrick. and there is a hawthorn tree there onto which people tie personal belongings, symbolizing ‚Äúhanding over our personal challenges to the Divine.‚Äù

**the signage in town:**

‚ÄúSt Patrick‚Äôs Well, one of Wicklows best known heritage sites is said to have been blessed by St Patrick on his travels around Ireland, some one & a half thousand years ago. The well in turn gives its name to the local area of Toberpatrick, ‚ÄúTober‚Äù being the irish for ‚ÄúThe Well‚Äù, thus ‚Äúthe well of Patrick.‚Äù The well provided a source of excellent spring water for the families in the local area. The water was transported by a locally designed and built, horse drawn water cart. ‚Äú

i randomly happened upon a town that was so close to a well that was called ‚Äúthe well of patrick‚Äù? because my legs hurt and i couldn‚Äôt go on farther? it was meant to be: i definitely need to leave some ashes at ‚Äúthe well of patrick.‚Äù but it‚Äôs a 3.5 mile walk on my rest day. the taxi app has nothing available in this area. i checked google to see how easy the walk may be.

‚ÄúIt is situated on Baileys Farm in County Wicklow. The owners, the Hayden family supply milk for Baileys Irish Cream.‚Äù

sold! i‚Äôll make the trek, bagless and it shouldn‚Äôt be too bad. i head back into the hotel to grab some water and my steripen, in case the well is still in use. it would be cool to drink from patrick‚Äôs well. i check in with the new bartender, a very pretty young irish girl who was very cheerful. and easier for me to understand than the older woman last night.

‚Äúis the walk to toberpatrick easy to follow?‚Äù

‚Äúyes very! it‚Äôs a wee far tho.‚Äù she replied.

‚Äúi noticed.‚Äù the times on google map make me laugh for everything. 3.5 mile walk: 1 hour and 40 minute walk or ‚Ä¶ 7 minute drive. the hills‚Äôll getcha! ‚Äúany interest in driving me there for ‚Ç¨20?‚Äù

‚Äúi‚Äôd drive ye for nuttin, but i‚Äôm working till half 8!‚Äù

‚Äúalright, i‚Äôll be back in 3 hours!‚Äù it was 3 pm already. this would be a nice walk before dinner. ‚Äúlast question. is the well still used?‚Äù

‚Äúi wouldn‚Äôt!‚Äù she laughed.

the walk was mostly on roads just barely enough for 2 cars let alone pedestrians. and the cars never seemed to notice you walking until the very last second. it was warm and my fleece started sticking to my sweaty arms, so i took it off. about 2 miles in, google tells me ‚Äúturn right on unnamed road for a half mile, make a left on unnamed road.‚Äù you have to love that. i don‚Äôt know what we would do without modern gps and mapping technology. as recently as a couple months ago, the girl i was dating smacked my phone out of my hand ‚Äúyou and your google! let‚Äôs wander around until we find somewhere to eat or something that looks fun.‚Äù she wasn‚Äôt wrong! i do that all the time when i‚Äôm traveling, but in my hometown i like to be direct i guess. but not as direct as my deceased friend pat mulhern. that man would put his gps on even if he was going 3 blocks away. we used to bust his balls for that all the time. i laughed to myself when i thought about just how crazy that was, and thought maybe i should try the wander method more at home.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4151.jpg?w=1024)

> st. patrick‚Äôs well

i arrive at the religious well, a serene and very calming and unassuming landmark tucked behind an old wooden fence. i snap a photo of the sign and advance toward a craggily twisted tree with lots of pieces of clothing tied to the branches. there are personal photos, i assume of sick or dead loved ones. there are statues of st patrick and candles surrounding the well that has a spring running from it.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4154.jpg?w=1024)

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4155.jpg?w=1024)

> tying personal belongings to the tree

there‚Äôs a nice bench to the left. i sit down and have a rest, and think about those that i‚Äôve lost over the years, including my grandparents, uncle vince, aunt helene, uncle tom. and i take out the glass vials of ashes from my pocket and rest them on the bench. the well started bubbling up, air escaping from the rocks below? water filling the well from the water table? my dad patrick or patrick mulhern saying hello?

<https://blossom.primal.net/f8806464b0afae112bb7e50100c79a080eb57d54177c4aa5743035bc163c7b70.mp4>

> bubbling well

i decided not to put the ashes in the well water, just in case it was actually used. i opted instead for scattering them at the roots of the hawthorn tree. i opened both vials and tapped the rims to let the ashes out.

<https://blossom.primal.net/477012cd00e134104060c157e5d053adf051c146db99264ea6d0e3093eaaa173.mp4>

> spreading some ashes at ‚Äúpatrick‚Äôs well‚Äú

i grabbbed my hydro flask and dumped out the rest of the water and then filled it with the well water. why not! i‚Äôm here! i used the steripen for 90 seconds to purify the water. i took a small sip to taste any obvious bad tastes. tasted like pure spring water. i chugged half a liter, a little too aggressively. some spilled out near the corner of my mouth. oops! hurriedly, i screwed the cap back on as it was about to start raining (the first rain i would see so far on my trip). i looked down to wipe off any obvious water drops from my shirt. at that moment i realized i was wearing my ‚Äúphrolic‚Äù tshirt with my dad‚Äôs face on it. how appropriate!

looking down to wipe my hand along my chest to knock off spilled water, i stopped and started laughing. the water drops look like two teardrops from my dad‚Äôs eyes. i shit you not! now if i was a religious man, i would see this as a sure sign from the afterlife. and i know some of you reading this will assure me later that it was! but i took it as a comical coincidence that honestly, my dad would have thoroughly loved.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4167.jpg?w=473)

> don‚Äôt cry over spilt water

```
story time! before my oldest sibling sara was born, my mom and dad had a miscarriage. naturally, they didn‚Äôt think that they would be able to get pregnant as a result. my dad claimed he had 3 dreams where the blessed mother came to him and told him ‚Äúfear not paddy, you will have a beautiful daughter. and you will name her sara.‚Äù he wrote those dreams down on a piece of paper, sealed it in an envelope, and kept it forever. as you are aware, they did indeed have a daughter, and they named her sara. he added some flair by making her middle name maria, in honor of mary. my dad had always felt a special connection to the blessed mother. a few years before he passed, he started to give away his possessions. he wanted to be there to watch us receive his treasures (his scab collection, his shrunken head, his vinyl collection‚Ä¶ all the good stuff). it‚Äôs more fun to watch your collections be cherished by someone new than to sit stuffed in a box. especially something as meaningful as his sealed dreams, which he gave to sara and she still has yet to unseal to this day.
```

it started drizzling, so i quickly packed everything and threw on my raincoat. i started walking back to the hotel. it rained for only about 10 minutes.

when i got back to the hotel, i soaked my legs again. they still weren‚Äôt feeling right. but the pain was tolerable. later that night i headed out to the only other bar in town that was open, o‚Äôconnor‚Äôs. what a difference it was than the one last night. as i‚Äôm walking in, a limo bus pulls up. i hear a bar employee say ‚Äúoh yer that rugby players innit?‚Äù he was. who that was, i don‚Äôt know. i continue walking in and the bartender asks ‚Äúare you with the wedding?‚Äù oh boy! here we go!

it was a monday night, so i was surprised a wedding party would be arriving. it was 3 buses of irish, from 12 years old to 80 years old.

‚Äúis the whole place rented for a private event?‚Äù i asked, seeing if i needed to sneak in.

‚Äúnope, have a seat at the bar!‚Äù with pleasure! if i know irish weddings, i knew i was about to meet some people at what would be the busiest place in the building that night.

the bride‚Äôs sister was the first to come up. the bride and groom have been together for 15 years, but he finally popped the question so this was going to be ‚Äúa BIG celebration.‚Äù she asked to do a shot with me, so of course i obliged with a hearty slainte. the bartender told me that the families rented out ballybeg house, a short way down the road. i wonder if i passed it on my walk to the well. this place does many a fancy wedding, and you have to rent the entire place out for 3 or 4 day affairs, usually a couple years ahead of time. they usually do at least 2 weddings a week, he said. having attended mick and ann marie‚Äôs 4 day fest, this wasn‚Äôt a terrible surprise to me. this was the pre-celebration, with the wedding the following night (tuesday). i found that rather interesting. i‚Äôve never been to a tuesday wedding, but the ballybeg house sounded like an economic engine for this small village in county wicklow.

i met two of the brothers of the groom. the first came up to me ‚Äúare ye irish?‚Äù ‚Äúnope, american.‚Äù ‚Äúhah, i win. he‚Äôs not.‚Äù they had bet if i was irish or a tourist. they actually both have lived in nashville, tennessee for the last 10 years. i commented ‚Äúoh wow you still have your accents!‚Äù the older brother replied ‚Äúi come back often. i hafta keep me accent. it‚Äôs how i get tha girls!‚Äù i met the father of the groom, who seemed to be paying for the open bar. incredibly gregarious and grateful for the turnout. and i met the youngest guy at the bar who shyly asked the bartender for ‚Äúa schmirnof ice. BUT it‚Äôs not for me. i‚Äôm prankin‚Äô me father.‚Äù the bartender laughed, didn‚Äôt mind his prepubescence, and gave him the ice. i watched him sneak it under his dad‚Äôs seat, and when he returned from the bathroom, asked his dad to grab something he dropped under his seat. ICED! his dad had to chug the rather disgusting drink. man, i hadn‚Äôt see that in years and had a good chuckle. the son was laughing hysterically. i met some friends of the bride and friends of the groom, many of whom started the conversation with ‚Äúyer the yank, huh?‚Äù or ‚Äúyer the guy from philly, yeah?‚Äù by the number of people that offered me a shot (i only did a couple with the bridal party members), i could tell the wedding would be a fun time.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4169.jpg?w=768)

> this soup course took me back to 2003, my first time in ireland. when all i could afford was soup. i‚Äôll still contend that ireland makes some of the best soups i‚Äôve ever had. this one was superb.

between meeting wedding goers, i had a fabulous meal and discussion with the two bartenders, ois√≠n and aoife. oisin was a young irish guy, born in puerto rico, lived in panama, but mostly has lived in every area of ireland. he has an american passport but has never been to america since his toddler years in puerto rico, even tho his sister lives near lake tahoe in california. aoife was a gorgeous young irish girl, with a charming smile and a very thick accent. her eyes twinkled when she smiled. she has lived here her whole life. both gave me their suggestions about where i should go (connemara and the ring of kerry seemed to be consensus. ‚Äúperfect! that‚Äôs where my trip ends!‚Äù) both said the last leg of the wicklow way was the worst, because it‚Äôs on a lot of roads. but neither had done it for themselves, so i ignored that. aoife ‚Äúcouldn‚Äôt be caught dead‚Äù drinking water from random sources. ‚Äúwhat are ye, mental?‚Äù oisin wasn‚Äôt into hiking, and would rather play football. when i asked why no one in the wedding party was drinking guinness, but instead drank heineken, oisin said ‚Äúlet me put this in terms ye‚Äôd understand. yer in red neck country! we have no taste.‚Äù

i was glad i stayed in tinahely a second night. my impressions of it changed rather quickly when i actually was in a better mood myself, and when i sat and talked to the lifeblood of the town. this is the kind of town i really enjoy visiting. i feel like you get a much better taste of irish culture here than from dublin or cork or killarney. it‚Äôs not that i don‚Äôt also love the bigger cities, but i feel like a lot of times in those cities, you end up meeting americans or other travelers ‚Äî when what i‚Äôm here for is the irish.

the wedding pre-party was slowing down, saving their energy for the big night i guess. either that or the open bar was closing and they‚Äôd head back to drink at ballybeg house. so with that, i also settled up and started to head back to the hotel myself. my lower leg was starting to throb, and i wanted to give it ample rest before a long trek tomorrow. as i was leaving, the brothers said ‚Äúif yer in the area tomorrow, crash the weddin!‚Äù i considered staying again in tinahely. but i only had 2 change of clothes total for my trip, and neither hiking pants or hiking shorts are wedding-worthy. and both were getting stinky. the next laundromat or male‚Äôs clothing store were miles away. ‚Äúi will!‚Äù i lied. ‚Äúhave a blast! and congrats!‚Äù i throw back the rest of my guinness.

my glass was empty but *my cup *was full.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4174.jpg?w=1024)

> 10:30 pm ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

it was roughly 10:30pm when i left the bar. and it was still dusk lighting. that throws me for a loop every time. goodnight tinahely, thanks for giving me a break and letting my tired legs recover.

posts.title: day four: on the way to tinahely üé∂
posts.summary: SERIES REPOST 2022: day four (~21 miles; ~73 total) pushed me to my limit ‚Äî no coffee, scarce water, and a grueling final descent into tinahely. between a fox at dawn, worms in my rainwater, and aching legs begging for mercy, i learned that sometimes survival looks like a hot soak, a burger, and a well-earned pint.
posts.content:
> *\[ Edited: 10/25/2025 this is a repost of a series i wrote in 2022, migrating it to the new nostr website ]*

**DAY FOUR HIKE:** \~21 miles\
**TOTAL HIKE:** \~73 miles

i made a cardinal sin last night. i didn‚Äôt put my phone into airplane mode. being half way down a valley, the reception was non-existent in the hut. the phone searched all night for better coverage, and when i awoke it was half way drained. eek!

i took out the power bank and carried it and the phone together, sandwiched together while i brought new life to the phone. this power bank feels like it‚Äôs 1.5 or 2 pounds (it‚Äôs a big battery for 2 full phone charges in case i needed it). carrying it while hiking is awkward and adds strain to my hand. but i didn‚Äôt want to wait at camp for it to charge. the town of glenmalure is a short distance ahead, i would get breakfast there and hope i could put the charger away after. so for the first day i don‚Äôt have my coffee and set off at around 7:30am.

i am feeling great. feeling strong. ready for a marathon of a day to knock some mileage out and see some more beautiful landscapes. as i turn around the first bend in the road, headed down further into the valley to glenmalure, a fox runs across the trail, taking me by surprise. another hundred meters down the road, and a big buck is grazing on a berry bush and we scare each other. active morning in the woods!

i arrive at glenmalure at around 8am. and the restaurant/pub that‚Äôs on my map is not yet open. this place looks fun (live music!) and if i knew it was this close, i may have tempted coming down from the hut for a beer and trad music session (but leaving my bag would have been stupid?).

well shoot, that was the only water source on the map (‚Äúfill at pub‚Äù) in a couple mile radius. i was banking on them! i look outside to see if there‚Äôs a tap at all, as i had seen at one or two small farms along the way. a small tap with a worn and weathered hand written ‚Äúdrinking water‚Äù sign on it. very gracious to the farmers when i see those.

alas, nothing. no breakfast. no water. no coffee. so i keep walking, with the clunky power brick in hand. i continue the trek and eventually see the private campground that was option 2 for last night after the hut. it‚Äôs behind a locked fence. glad i didn‚Äôt pass up the empty hut! i continue up the forest path. shortly thereafter, tmy ears perk up. running water!

there‚Äôs something so very primal about the sound of running water. even when i was full, and deep in thought, the sound of running water would snap me out of my head and back into reality. y*ou need water to survive. do you have enough? *thank you, primal instincts. no, i do not have enough this morning. i wiggle through the first couple feet of dense trees and find a nice stream of clear water. there‚Äôs also a clearing of flat land. i marked both the water source and the potential wild camp site on the hiiker map for to next person debating how far they can make it to their next campsite.

the next couple mile trek took me back up into the clouds with some nice views along the way. several parts were on the road with bicyclists whizzing by. i couldn‚Äôt imagine going at the speed they were going: both up and downhill. my initial idea for this trip was biking the wild atlantic way, 1600 miles long the western coast. it‚Äôs amazing scenery‚Ä¶ but seeing all these hills and mountains, i‚Äôm sure glad i didn‚Äôt pursue that. plus, i like walking way more than i like biking.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4085.jpg?w=1024)

> aghavannagh, so remote that inhabitants say it ‚Äúis the last place god made‚Äù

i saw a bunch of people the last couple of days. so far today, i‚Äôve seen no one. as i‚Äôm climbing down a boulder path, a long way down, wide enough for one person, i jump at the sound of footsteps behind me. i didn‚Äôt hear him coming, but an irish runner was *running* down this boulder path! what!? how!? it was rather impressive. he takes out his ear buds,

‚Äúhiya! i see yer pack, you doing the whole way?‚Äù

‚Äúyep! trying to do the coast to coast actually!‚Äù

‚Äúthat‚Äôs great! where did ye stay last night.‚Äù

‚Äújust outside glenmalure in that hut.‚Äù

‚Äúwas it clean? people are arseholes and leave trash a lot.‚Äù

‚Äúit was perfect!‚Äù

‚Äúyou made good time. what time did you start, half six?‚Äù

‚Äúabout 7:30. i‚Äôm about to stop for lunch.‚Äù

‚Äúcarry on! good luck!‚Äù

and he sped up and left my field of vision in seconds. impressive.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4088.jpg?w=1024)

> still carrying that charger. awkward! nicest of the huts!

i arrived at the last hut on the trail. it was about a 7 mile hike in 2 1/2 hours. but it was pretty hot and i drank most of the 2L water. i read this hut had a rain water collection tank on the side, so i tested to make sure it had water in it. turned it on quickly, felt lots of pressure, turned it off. great! so i chugged the rest of what i had in the camelback and half the hydro flask. then i opened a granola and berries meal pack, used the rest of the water to rehydrate it and to make some coffee. i‚Äôm sitting at the hut and notice the guest book so i crack it open. lots of entries from families thankful for the place to stay. lots of couples doing weekend hikes. lots doing the whole of wicklow way. lots of people, like me, using it as a place to eat lunch. someone stayed here each of the last 4 beautiful weather nights. i used the broken pen to write a little note and leave encouragement for the next person to read it. i mention the ashes i have been dropping along the route, and how i stayed in the hut outside of glenmalure. ‚Äúi will keep an eye out if you raise money to build more huts!‚Äù.

![](https://gowithbflow.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/img_4086.jpg?w=768)

> the guest book has seen better days! almost every page in the book was filled up.

i‚Äôm still hungry. i didn‚Äôt eat dinner last night because i went to bed early. so i figure i‚Äôll make another food pack. i opted for the pesto chicken pasta. i just needed to refill water.

i head to the rain collector. water gushes out into my hydro flask. i look in and there are a lot of floaties. i def wish i brought a filter. i used the fabric of a shirt i wasn‚Äôt wearing to cover the mouth of the hydro flask. and pour the water into the stove pot to boil it.

i looked at the fabric after pouring and almost gagged. there were small larva or worms wiggling around on the shirt. maybe a half inch long each. gross. and i just drank all my water! (i didn‚Äôt get a picture) well, i boiled the heck out of the strained water. made my pasta pack, which was surpassingly good. and i drank the remainder of the boiled 1/2 liter as hot water. i was not keen on the idea of filling up water with the worms again. so i left my tanks empty and hoped for the best. i basically just ate/drank 3 liters so i should be fine.

before i left, i tried to figure out lodging. i screwed the pooch (that saying is‚Ä¶ weird) with the airplane mode snafu and now i drained my backup battery. so i needed to find a b\&b or hotel. i couldn‚Äôt find much available but about 14 miles away was a small town of tinahely, about a mile and half off the trail. that looked good. i checked the [booking.com](http://booking.com) app and they had a room available. and the room had a bathtub for a soak. BINGO. booked it for ‚Ç¨140. expensive but whatever, helping the irish economy! now to get 14 miles with no water. easy peazy.

> my walk gets rudely interrupted by an irish traffic jam. i tried to talk to these guys but only got a ‚Äúhow are ye.‚Äù they were busy and i was tired. so i kept going after the jam cleared out.

this leg of the hike was grueling, particularly the last few miles. i was at close to 20 miles with lots of downhill on hard road and lots of uphill on slick sheep shit. it was grueling. i was getting emotionally and physically drained. i came to a junction point. and could have gotten to town two different ways. one went up. the other went down. clearly i took the down route, hoping it was mostly down into the valley. i didn‚Äôt think i could make it another ascent, literally. my legs were sore. my feet were exploding out of sides of my boots. i needed water badly. (i had refilled at a stream since the hut, and drank 3 L but i needed more by this point and was bone dry again).

feeling completely drained, i think i let out an audible whimper and a whiny ‚Äúwhyyy‚Ä¶‚Äù when i saw i had to climb a fence. i took my time, careful not to fall over from exhaustion. 1.5 miles more. 1.5 miles until a hot soak in a tub. 1.3 miles more. 1.3 miles until a hot meal and a beer. 1 mile more. man this road is not ending. *1.5 miles‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs about 10 minutes at my fast running pace. why am i only going 100 feet in 10 minutes.*

i stopped half way down in front of a young family‚Äôs house to rest. my feet felt as if i had walked on sharp glass all day. and the hard asphalt was not helping. i took off my bag, sat on a rock for a couple a minutes and wondered out loud ‚Äúi think this pace is unsustainable. at least with me carrying this fooker the whole way.‚Äù i kick mr. osprey and he falls over. ugh. i loosen my shoelaces a bit. when i do this i realize i‚Äôm not wearing my hiking socks. i‚Äôm still wearing my post-hike campsite compression socks. maybe this is why my feet feel particularly bad today? i have never had shin splints before but i start to feel a pain in my shins. that‚Äôs something to watch for, i think to myself.

a young woman comes out of the house, gets into her car, waves a friendly hello. *please offer me a ride the last mile!* *please! *outwardly i was smiling and waving back, but i must have had a hardened scowl on my face, one of agony and grit. because she just drove away without opening her passenger door!

a mile‚Ä¶ i got this. i picked up my bag, threw it over my back, and did the old man shuffle down the rest of the hill, moving my feet barely off the ground and going 10 inches at a time. it did the trick.

tinahely is a small village with a population under 1000 people. but they had everything i needed to, as i had decided on that last painful descent, take a day off tomorrow and rest. my legs needed it. my shoulders needed it. my spirit and well-being needed it. it was the most trying day so far, but the hike was as gorgeous as the day was long. exploring the town will have to wait until tomorrow. i have a hot soak, a burger, and a beer to attend to!

> my well earned burger, the irish beef is from the farm attached to the restaurant! i got fried egg and irish bacon on top of the burger, because protein and calories and mmmmm.

posts.content:
In this week‚Äôs Ag Tribes Report, host Vance Crowe is joined by dairy farmer and Bitcoiner JR Burdick for a fast-paced tour through the biggest stories shaping agriculture. They unpack President Trump‚Äôs viral post urging ranchers to lower beef prices and the backlash from cattle producers who point to low herd size, packer settlements, and market volatility driven by political posts. Then they dig into the looming SNAP crunch amid the government shutdown, how an AWS outage jammed up harvest logistics and farmgate payments, and the partial reopening of FSA offices to process $3B in producer payments‚Äîplus the real-world cash flow pinch for beginning farmers. JR also delivers the Bitcoin Land Price Report, shares why he‚Äôs bullish on both land and Bitcoin, and explains practical resiliency lessons from a payments outage. We close with his Peter Thiel paradox‚ÄîGen Z‚Äôs push to rebuild rural ‚Äúplace‚Äù over ‚Äúcareer‚Äù‚Äîand a candid look at rebuilding community, selling raw milk and pastured pork, and accepting Bitcoin on the farm.

posts.title: VCP: Devon Eriksen on cowards, leftists and culture change
posts.summary: In this episode, Vance Crowe sits down with author Devon Erickson to explore why he calls himself a compulsive explainer and how he sees the role of an intellectual: not to end debates, but to start
posts.content:
In this episode, Vance Crowe sits down with author Devon Erickson to explore why he calls himself a compulsive explainer and how he sees the role of an intellectual: not to end debates, but to start them with powerful metaphors and fresh lenses. They dive deep into empathy as a writer‚Äôs core skill‚Äîsimultaneously inhabiting a character‚Äôs inner world and anticipating the reader‚Äôs experience‚Äîand how that practice shapes Devon‚Äôs science-fiction novel, Theft of Fire. From first-person perspective and memory palaces to the mechanics of metaphor in thought, they wander into bigger terrain: how online discourse reveals public preoccupations, why villains must believe they‚Äôre right, and what it takes to write convincingly across gender and worldview.

Their conversation also ranges into contested civic ground: the difference between empathy and sympathy, the dynamics of thug mentality and civilized restraint, the risks of escalating political tribalism, and the notion of ‚Äúsoft off-ramps‚Äù in American politics. They talk about immigration enforcement as theater versus necessity, institutional capture, and the appeal of centralized control to academics. Then they zoom back to the personal: metabolic health and processed food, the economic pressures on families, inflation as time theft, Bitcoin as an intergenerational lifeboat, and why some boomers feel out of touch with younger realities. They close with Devon‚Äôs passion project‚Äîthe cinematic, full-cast audiobook of Theft of Fire‚Äîand the promise of classic sci-fi spirit with modern tech rigor.
